data.title: Vodafone to Start Simultaneous On-Sale of Shrs by GSI to Vodafone
South Korea's Kospi Rises 1.1%, Led by Defense, Shipbuilding Stocks — Market Talk
data.description: South Korea's benchmark Kospi rose 1.1% to close at 2481.69, led by defense and shipbuilding stocks. President Trump's delay in imposing tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada eased trade-war fears to support sentiment, but concerns linger as China hit back against new U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods. Foreign and institutional investors were net buyers. Guided-missile maker LIG Nex1 climbed 8.6%. Shipbuilder Hanwha Ocean rose 6.7%. Chemical company LG Chem and steelmaker Posco Holdings fell 4.1% and 4.8%, respectively, after weak 4Q earnings. USD/KRW settled 0.3% lower at 1,462.90 in Seoul onshore trading. South Korea's 10-year government bond yield was up 1.5 bps at 2.850%. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

data.title: Infineon Lifts Sales Guidance After Boost From AI Chips — Update
data.description:
By Mauro Orru

Infineon Technologies raised its sales forecasts for the fiscal year amid solid demand for chips to power servers and data centers behind the artificial-intelligence boom.

The German chip maker said revenue would be flat to slightly up in the year to the end of September from the 14.96 billion euros ($15.94 billion) it reported for fiscal 2024. Infineon had previously forecast a slight decline. Meanwhile, Infineon's segment result margin--a key profitability measure--is still expected in the mid-to-high-teens percentage range.

The upgrade comes after what Infineon said was a slightly better start to the fiscal year than expected amid a boost in semiconductors sales for servers and data centers to power AI. However, areas of the semiconductor industry outside of artificial intelligence continue to suffer from sluggish demand.

Orders for legacy chips found in cars and industrial equipment has been subdued in recent months as car makers and manufacturers of industrial machinery cut spending since they stockpiled the semiconductors they needed years ago.

The divergence in demand between AI chips and legacy semiconductors meant that chip makers with significant AI exposure like Nvidia have grown exponentially, while companies such as Infineon that mostly sell chips to the automotive sector and makers of industrial equipment have struggled.

Infineon slashed its sales guidance three times in the previous fiscal year. Last week, Tesla supplier STMicroelectronics said it was expecting lower sales this quarter, citing challenges in demand for legacy semiconductors.

"Following the expected inventory reduction, we continue to anticipate that the recovery in demand will be gradual for the current fiscal year," Infineon Chief Executive Jochen Hanebeck said.

The company posted 3.42 billion euros in sales in the three months to the end of December, down 8% on year. Infineon's automotive division--which accounts for the lion's share of revenue--logged a 8% contraction in sales. Only the power and sensor systems business reported an increase in sales, lifted by chips for servers and data centers.

Net profit declined to 246 million euros from 587 million euros, while Infineon's segment result contracted to 573 million euros from 831 million euros, generating a 16.7% margin.

Analysts had forecast quarterly sales of nearly 3.23 billion euros, a net profit of 252 million euros, a segment result of 477 million euros and a 14.8% margin, according to a Vara Research consensus.

For the current quarter, Infineon is expecting sales of around 3.6 billion euros and a segment result margin in the mid-teens percentage range.

Write to Mauro Orru at mauro.orru@wsj.com

data.title: Southwest Securities International Takeover Bid Lapses
data.description:
Southwest Securities International Securities , said a proposed sale and purchase agreement for a majority stake in the company has lapsed.

The agreement, which would have seen Wong Man Hin Max acquire 74.1% of the company's issued share capital, was terminated after Wong was unable to secure the necessary financing.

Wong had offered to purchase 2,713,469,233 shares in the company held by Southwest Securities International Investment, the company's controlling shareholder.

data.title: Nintendo Cuts Earnings, Switch Sales Guidance
data.description:
(06:31 GMT) *Nintendo Cuts Revenue, Net-Profit Views for FY Ending March
(06:33 GMT) *Nintendo Cuts FY Switch Console, Software Sales Forecasts
(06:34 GMT) *Mitsubishi Electric 3Q Net Profit Beat Y82.88B Expected in Poll of Analysts by FactSet>6503.TO
(06:35 GMT) *Nintendo Expects to Sell 11.0M Switch Consoles This FY Vs 12.5M Previously Forecast
(06:36 GMT) *Nintendo Expects to Sell 150.0M Switch Software Copies This FY Vs 160.0M Previously Forecast
(07:13 GMT) Nintendo Cuts Earnings, Switch Sales Guidance

By Kosaku Narioka

Nintendo cut its annual projections for earnings and Switch console sales after weak results for the nine months ended December.

The Japanese videogame maker said Tuesday that net profit dropped 42% from a year earlier to 237.19 billion yen, equivalent to $1.53 billion, for the nine-month period. Revenue fell 31% to Y956.22 billion.

The Switch console, launched in 2017, was a runaway success for Nintendo, which has had a spotty record with hardware, but sales of the aging console are now firmly in decline.

Nintendo said in January that it would start selling the successor to its nearly eight-year-old console this year, but didn't reveal the price, the launch date nor specifications.

The company now expects to sell 11.0 million Switch consoles for the year ending March, down from 12.5 million units forecast previously, and 150 million software copies, lower than its previous view of 160 million copies.

Nintendo projected net profit to drop 45% to Y270.00 billion and revenue to decline 29% to Y1.190 trillion this fiscal year.

The videogame maker has been diversifying its revenue streams with some success, offering other forms of entertainment by leveraging its popular characters and game series.

Write to Kosaku Narioka at kosaku.narioka@wsj.com

data.title: Mitsubishi UFJ 9-Mos Net Trading Profit Y288.13B Vs Y321.12B
Black Peony to Invest In 100 Million Yuan New Energy Fund
data.description:
Black Peony Group agreed to be one of the investors of a 100 million yuan partnership fund, according to a Jan. 24 filing with the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

The fund, Changzhou Xinbei District Hejiaxin Carbon Venture Capital Partnership (Limited Partnership), has a six-year term and will mainly invest in enterprises in new energy, advanced carbon materials, manufacturing and other upstream and downstream industrial chains in China's Changzhou National Hi-Tech Zone.

The Chinese urban construction company will invest 19 million yuan through its subsidiary, Changzhou Mudanjiangnan Venture Capital, accounting for 19% of the fund.

data.title: U.S. 10-Year Yield Edges Up as Trump Delays Mexico, Canada Tariffs — Market Talk
data.description:
0714 GMT - U.S. 10-year Treasury yields trade slightly higher after President Trump agreed with leaders of Mexico and Canada to delay the introduction of tariffs for a month. The delay comes as Mexico and Canada agreed to take measures to tackle the trafficking of fentanyl across the U.S. border. Trump's roulette affirms the newfound risk-off/risk-on patterns, says Commerzbank Research's Christoph Rieger. The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield rises 2.5 basis points to 4.569%, while the 2-year Treasury yield is flat at 4.266%, according to Tradeweb. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0714 GMT - China's first shots in the trade war look largely symbolic, Oxford Economics says. Beijing responded to Trump's 10% blanket tariffs on Chinese imports with a series of tariffs on U.S. products like coal. By OE's estimates, the move raises the weighted effective tariff rate on U.S. imports into China by close to +2ppt, "thereby a more symbolic move for now." The blanket-style U.S. tariffs plus stronger retaliation language imply a very high chance of further action by the U.S., economist Louise Loo says. OE thinks China will continue with meticulously targeted tariff lists and lean on defensive measures like tax rebates and support for exporters. It may also deploy export controls and probes into U.S. companies. As markets price more uncertainty, the yuan is likely to come under continued pressure, OE says. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0712 GMT - South Korea's benchmark Kospi rose 1.1% to close at 2481.69, led by defense and shipbuilding stocks. President Trump's delay in imposing tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada eased trade-war fears to support sentiment, but concerns linger as China hit back against new U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods. Foreign and institutional investors were net buyers. Guided-missile maker LIG Nex1 climbed 8.6%. Shipbuilder Hanwha Ocean rose 6.7%. Chemical company LG Chem and steelmaker Posco Holdings fell 4.1% and 4.8%, respectively, after weak 4Q earnings. USD/KRW settled 0.3% lower at 1,462.90 in Seoul onshore trading. South Korea's 10-year government bond yield was up 1.5 bps at 2.850%. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

0705 GMT - Japanese shares closed higher, in line with most Asian markets, which took a breather after U.S. President Trump agreed to postpone the start of tariffs on Mexico and Canada by a month. The Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.7% to 38798.37. The index trimmed earlier gains after China announced retaliatory tariffs on some U.S. goods. Auto and financial stocks advanced. Toyota Motor was up 1.7%, while Nissan Motor closed 0.7% higher. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial gained 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. USD/JPY was at 154.79, compared with 155.37 as of Monday 5 p.m. Eastern time. (venkat.pr@wsj.com)

0700 GMT - French government bonds modestly outperformed German peers on Monday but being long in French bonds still carries some risks, says Danske Bank's Jens Peter Sorensen in a note. French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou pushed the 2025 budget bill without a vote by lawmakers, and faces a no-confidence vote. Using a constitutional tool to pass the bill "was what led to fall of the previous French government," the fixed income research director says. "Hence, there is still some considerable risks to being long France even at spread of some 75 basis points in the 10-year area to Germany," Sorensen says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0642 GMT - Higher tariffs have the potential to increase inflation in the short term if companies pass the costs on to their customers, says Damian McIntyre at Federated Hermes. However, this is unlikely to impact central bank policy in the longer term, says the head of multi-asset solutions in a note. "We would expect this to be a one-off impact of inflation, rather than a sustained increase," he says. In the short term, this could keep rates higher for longer, he adds. Federated Hermes, however, does not expect it to have long-term implications for central bank policy. U.S. President Trump and the leaders of Mexico and Canada reached a deal to put tariffs on hold for a month. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0633 GMT - China's retaliation to Trump's tariffs doesn't seem aggressive, says Zhiwei Zhang, president and chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management. Beijing's measures only target some U.S. products, whereas the U.S. tariffs apply to all Chinese exports to the country, says Zhang. "This is likely only the beginning of a long process for the two countries to negotiate," the economist says. The negotiations between the U.S. and its neighbors suggest that there is some hope of de-escalation at some point, though the road ahead is likely to be bumpy, Zhang says. Washington postponed tariffs on Canada and Mexico after reaching border-related deals. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0629 GMT - ​The top risk for 2025 identified by ETF provider Global X was policy sequencing across taxes, tariffs and deregulation. These are now now playing out, potentially causing more volatility in rates markets, says Scott Helfstein, head of investment strategy. "This is likely a source for increased volatility in the rate market more so than serious disruption for companies and equities, but this is early days," he says in a note. U.S. President Trump moved to levy tariffs on Mexico and Canada, but the leaders of the three states reached an agreement to put tariffs on hold for a month. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0437 GMT - The real impact of U.S. tariffs is too early to determine, according to Stephen Dover, chief market strategist and head of the Franklin Templeton Institute, in a commentary. It is unclear whether these tariffs are a long-term policy or a negotiation tactic by President Trump to secure concessions, the strategist notes. At the margin, these tariffs should encourage more domestic production of goods in the United States. However, the uncertainty surrounding the permanence of these tariffs makes it challenging for companies to make informed capital investment decisions, Dover adds. Chinese policymakers and businesses are likely to implement measures to mitigate the impact should the situation escalate further, Dover notes. (tracy.qu@wsj.com)

0431 GMT - China could ramp up foreign direct investment in 2025 to ease the impact of higher U.S. tariffs on its exports and the broader economy, ANZ economists say in a research note. Chinese companies have invested heavily in third countries like Mexico since the initial U.S.-China trade dispute in 2018. According to China's commerce ministry, 326 Chinese enterprises registered to invest in Mexico in 2023, up from 133 in 2020. The economists think the trend is not only tariff driven, but also due to supply chain shifts. "Low industrial profit under overcapacity concerns and relatively high production costs drives supply-chain shift overseas," they say. ANZ expects more overseas investment from Chinese companies to reduce reliance on traditional markets and diversify trade influence, they add. (sherry.qin@wsj.com)

0415 GMT - There are high hopes that China may strike a deal with President Trump to delay the additional 10% tariff, after Mexico and Canada managed to delay the U.S. tariffs, says IG. However, there is "still room for surprises and Trump could still come down hard", market strategist Yeap Jun Rong writes in a note. China is seen as a prominent threat to U.S. national security and economic competition, Yeap notes. The tech rivalry between the two countries has become even more pronounced recently with Chinese AI startup DeepSeek, he adds. "But if China can pull it off, risk sentiments may find further recovery momentum, at least in the near term," Yeap says.(amanda.lee@wsj.com)

0410 GMT - Indonesia's economy is expected to have grown 4.89% in 4Q 2024, slightly easing from 3Q's 4.95%, according to the median estimate of six economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. Growth was likely supported by a modest uptick in demand, despite slower investment growth amid the transition to a new head of state, DBS economists Taimur Baig and Nathan Chow say in a note. The 4Q outcome would peg 2024 growth at an average of 5%, maintaining a steady pace from 2023, they add. Indonesia's 2023 GDP growth was 5.05%. The data is due Wednesday. (yingxian.wong@wsj.com)

data.title: Mitsubishi UFJ 9-Mos Net Loss on Debt Securities Y221.18B Vs Loss Y197.03B

data.title: China's Retaliatory Tariffs Are Symbolic, Analyst Says — WSJ
data.description:
By Hannah Miao

China's early response to new tariffs from the U.S. is "a more symbolic move for now," Louise Loo, China lead economist at Oxford Economics, said in a report.

The move to impose retaliatory tariffs of up to 15% on select American goods would raise the weighted effective tariff rate on U.S. imports by around 2 percentage points, the advisory firm estimates. More rounds of tariffs are likely, given the U.S. said it would increase penalties if China responded with retaliatory levies, according to the firm. China could also weaken its currency and offer support to Chinese exporters to address tariffs, the report said.

This item is part of a Wall Street Journal live coverage event. The full stream can be found by searching P/WSJL (WSJ Live Coverage).

data.title: China's First Moves in Trade War Look Largely Symbolic — Market Talk
data.description: China's first shots in the trade war look largely symbolic, Oxford Economics says. Beijing responded to Trump's 10% blanket tariffs on Chinese imports with a series of tariffs on U.S. products like coal. By OE's estimates, the move raises the weighted effective tariff rate on U.S. imports into China by close to +2ppt, "thereby a more symbolic move for now." The blanket-style U.S. tariffs plus stronger retaliation language imply a very high chance of further action by the U.S., economist Louise Loo says. OE thinks China will continue with meticulously targeted tariff lists and lean on defensive measures like tax rebates and support for exporters. It may also deploy export controls and probes into U.S. companies. As markets price more uncertainty, the yuan is likely to come under continued pressure, OE says. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

data.title: Asia Markets Jittery as Traders Gauge First Trade War Salvos — Update
data.description:
By Kimberley Kao

Markets across Asia began the day with a relief rally after the U.S. struck last-minute deals with Mexico and Canada to delay tariffs, but the mood took a turn when no such reprieve materialized for China, which hit back with new tariffs on the U.S.

The news poured cold water on hopes that there would be talks between Washington and Beijing that could also lead to a postponing of the 10% tariffs on all Chinese goods entering the U.S.

As the U.S. tariffs took effect, Beijing retaliated by slapping levies on select U.S. imports, including coal, liquefied natural gas and crude oil. China's Commerce Ministry also said that it would tighten control of exports of some critical minerals but didn't single out exports to any particular country.

The earlier market cheer soured, with the offshore yuan weakening against the dollar, while benchmark indexes in Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea pared gains.

Oil futures extended losses, with front-month WTI crude oil futures down 1.8% to $71.83 per barrel, and Brent down 1.2% to $75.07 per barrel.

Bitcoin tumbled, falling below the key $100,000 handle.

Japan's Nikkei Stock Average closed 0.7% higher on Tuesday, after rising as much as 1.7% earlier in the session. Hong Kong's benchmark index lost some ground after China's announcement but remains about 2.3% higher, while South Korea's Kospi closed up 1.1%.

Other Asian stock markets also held their ground. Taiwan's Taiex index gained 0.4% and Malaysia's benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.5%.

Spot gold was broadly steady, sitting 0.1% lower at $2,811.23 per ounce

Amid the heightened tensions, China's market regulator Tuesday said it had opened an investigation into U.S. technology giant Google on suspected violation of antitrust law. Google didn't immediately respond to a request for comments.

Trump's aggressive move to place tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars in imports rattled investors, economists and some lawmakers.

In a social media post, Trump said that his administration will see in the next 30 days if an "economic deal" with Canada can be structured. He had made similar comments about Mexico.

"A headlines-driven market seems synonymous with Trump 2.0, much like in 2016," Yeap Jun Rong, market strategist at IG, said in a note.

Until recently, many on Wall Street viewed threats of the U.S. imposing the highest tariffs in decades as a negotiating tactic in border disputes over drug trafficking and migration, and unlikely to materialize.

"We still think that permanent tariffs on the U.S.'s allies (Canada, Mexico) will not be a thing," said Thierry Wizman, global foreign-exchange and rates strategist at Macquarie. "Tariffs [are] likely to be reversed before they do serious damage."

"That's because concessions are an 'easier' way to deal with Trump's 'problems'...and Trump likes to make 'deals,'" Wizman said in a note.

However, a deal might not be so easy in regards to China, analysts say.

The "overarching geo-economic dimensions to U.S.-China trade means that resolution will be far more fraught than is the case with Mexico and Canada," Vishnu Varathan, Mizuho Securities' head of macro research for Asia, excluding Japan, said in a note.

Relief isn't resolution, and Trump has warned that tariff plans are intact, Varathan said. U.S.-driven trade antagonism threats remain at large, and "it promises to be a bumpy ride for markets in the weeks ahead," with currency markets set up to be the most sensitive to U.S. tariff threats, he said.

The euro, Korean won, Thai baht, Malaysian ringgit, Australian dollar and offshore yuan remain on the line, Varathan said.

Zhiwei Zhang, president and chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management, said the new tariffs are "likely only the beginning of a long process for the two countries to negotiate."

Negotiations between the U.S. and its neighbors suggest that there is some hope of de-escalation at some point, though the road ahead is likely to be bumpy, Zhang said.

  • Fabiana Negrin Ochoa, Ronnie Harui and Farah Elias contributed to this article.

Write to Kimberley Kao at kimberley.kao@wsj.com

data.title: China Hits Back at Trump’s Tariffs, Launches Probe into Google
data.description:
China on Tuesday announced a package of tariffs on various US goods in immediate retaliation to a new 10% tariff on Chinese imports imposed by US President Donald Trump, which took effect today at 05:01 GMT. The Chinese finance ministry stated it would impose levies of 15% on US coal and LNG and 10% on crude oil, farm equipment, and certain autos, set to begin on February 10.

Separately, China’s State Administration for Market Regulation announced an investigation into a major US technology company over alleged violations of the country’s anti-monopoly law.

data.title: Diageo PLC 1H Sales Declined 0.6% in Reported Terms
DBS Adjusts CDL Hospitality Trusts' Price Target to SG$1.10 from SG$1.20, Keeps at Buy
data.description: CDL Hospitality Trusts has an average rating of hold and price targets ranging from SG$0.75 to SG$1.50, according to analysts polled by Capital IQ.

data.title: European Markets Struggle for Direction
data.description:
European equity futures struggled for direction early on Tuesday as investors weighed the latest shifts in global trade policy.

U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods came into effect earlier today, prompting Beijing to retaliate with its own tariffs on select U.S. exports, including oil, gas, coal, cars, and farm equipment, starting February 10.

Meanwhile, President Trump agreed late on Monday to “immediately pause” planned tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month, following successful negotiations with their respective leaders.

Trump had also previously threatened to impose levies on EU and UK products.

Investors are also looking ahead to earnings reports from major European firms, including UBS, BNP Paribas, and Dassault Systems. In premarket trading, Euro Stoxx 50 and Stoxx 600 futures fluctuated around the flatline.

data.title: Diageo PLC 1H Sales Rose 1% Organically
China Retaliates With New Levies, Antitrust Probe Into Google — WSJ
data.description:
By Liza Lin and Raffaele Huang

SINGAPORE — China hit back at fresh U.S. tariffs by imposing its own levies on U.S. goods and opening a probe into Google, sparking fears of a bigger trade war.

Beijing authorities also added several metals to an export control list, a move that highlights the vulnerability of global supply chains to materials from China.

The series of actions came days after President Trump said he would impose an additional 10% tariff on Chinese goods entering the U.S. Trump said he was responding to what he described as China's failure to prevent illegal fentanyl from entering America.

The new custom duties on Chinese goods took effect Tuesday. Trump had earlier called off separate tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods.

China's Finance Ministry said Tuesday it would impose 15% tariffs on U.S. coal and liquefied natural gas imports, as well as raise levies on crude oil, agricultural machinery and certain vehicles.

In a separate statement, the State Administration for Market Regulation, China's antitrust regulator, said it had begun an investigation into Google for possible antitrust violations. It didn't give the reason for the probe or other details.

Google's search engine and internet services for consumers have largely been unavailable in China since 2010. Currently, the Mountain View, Calif., company maintains limited operations in the country, including advertising and businesses related to its Android operating system.

Asian stock markets gave up some of their earlier gains Tuesday on news of China's actions. Markets are watching the outcome of trade tensions, which threaten to hit economic growth in China and other Asian exporters.

China is preparing its opening bid to negotiate with Trump, and its initial proposal will revolve around restoring a trade agreement that Beijing signed with the first Trump administration in 2020 but never enforced, The Wall Street Journal has reported.

Beijing will challenge Trump's new levies with a lawsuit at the World Trade Organization, said a spokesperson from the Commerce Ministry. The spokesperson called the U.S. actions a "blatant act of unilateralism and trade protectionism."

Elsewhere, Chinese authorities added PVH, the owner of Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, and American biotechnology company Illumina to an unreliable entity list. China said the two U.S. firms discriminated against Chinese companies.

PVH had been under investigation since September. China said it was looking into allegations that the American apparel firm boycotted cotton products from China's northwestern region of Xinjiang.

Xinjiang, a major cotton producer and home to millions of Muslim minorities, has been singled out by U.S. authorities who allege Chinese officials have carried out forced assimilation policies in the region. Beijing has denied such claims, saying its policies were combating terrorism and protecting national security.

Google, PVH and Illumina didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.

In the export-control action, the Commerce Ministry added several metals and metal-based products used in industrial machinery, aerospace and military applications to an control list. It didn't specify how the measures would affect sales to the U.S.

Tungsten, tellurium, bismuth, molybdenum and indium products were put on a list of items subject to review by Chinese authorities before they can be sold overseas.

Write to Liza Lin at liza.lin@wsj.com and Raffaele Huang at raffaele.huang@wsj.com

data.title: AKORA Resources To Raise AU$1.3 Million Via Share Placement, Shares Fall Past 3%
data.description:
AKORA Resources will raise AU$1.3 million via a share placement to existing and new investors, by issuing around 12.9 million new shares at an issue price of AU$0.10 per share, according to a Tuesday Australian bourse filing.

It expects to issue 7.9 million shares on or about Feb. 10 to existing and new investors as well as its management. It will then issue 3 million shares on or about Feb. 25.

Subsequently, it will issue 2 million shares to each member of its board, subject to shareholder approval at its general meeting, which is anticipated to occur in April.

It will use the proceeds to continue strategic investor discussions for the Bekisopa iron project in Madagascar, to progress key logistics arrangements, as well as for working capital.

The firm's shares fell past 3% on market close on Tuesday.

data.title: Market Chatter: Hong Kong Developers Poised to Launch Residential Projects
data.description:
The Lunar New Year will see more Hong Kong developers rolling out several new residential projects, The Standard reported Tuesday.

Among them are Chinachem, which will launch five residential projects, offering 720 new homes, the report said.

Henderson Land Development will also roll out six new projects totalling 3,700 units, according to the report.

New World Development's high-end residential project State Pavilia will roll out at least 78 apartments as early as next week, according to the report.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: Mitsubishi UFJ 9-Mos Net Interest Income Y2.174T Vs Y1.800T a Year Earlier
Jefferies Adjusts LIC Housing Finance's Price Target to INR700 From INR795, Keeps at Buy
data.description: LIC Housing Finance has an average rating of outperform and price targets ranging from 470 Indian rupees to 940 rupees, according to analysts polled by Capital IQ.

data.title: SEEDS Capital Appoints 20 New Partners for Co-Investment in Singapore Deep-Tech Startups
data.description:
SEEDS Capital enlisted 20 new partners to co-invest in Singapore-based deep tech startups, according to a Tuesday release.

The investment arm of Enterprise Singapore will invest SG$150 million over the next three years to generate another SG$300 million through its private sector partners in areas such as advanced manufacturing, agrifood tech, pharmabio/medtech, space tech and quantum tech as well as sustainability.

New co-investors include local firms like Temasek-backed Xora and ST Engineering Ventures and overseas companies such as Japan-based Global Brain, US-based Valuence Ventures, and Indonesia-based East Ventures.
